ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I greatly improved on my knowledge of Hindi and my speaking, reading, writing, and listening abilities. I really improved my conversation skills specifically through the weekly discussion sections with the teaching fellow and class discussion, and I very much appreciated that the emphasis was on speaking. I also improved my (hand)writing skills considerably and I am very happy with where I ended up -- at the beginning of the year I did not even know the Devanagari script. I also learned a lot more about the Hindi-speaking world and issues South Asia and the South Asian diaspora face.
Advanced hindi grammer
Learnt to converse, write, read. Also learnt grammar. Engaged in literature and culture.
Continued to improve on reading and writing, less of a focus on new grammar concepts as in L3.

I learned about different forms of Hindi grammar, increased my cultural knowledge about India and other South Asian countries, and gained a more expanded vocabulary (words related to science, the economy, health, the arts, education, etc). I also improved my script handwriting quality, as well as my reading and writing speed.
I learned advanced grammar concepts and improved on my speaking, reading, and writing abilities.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course's strength is definitely the instructors. Swapnaji was an absolutely wonderful and very engaging instructor. Additionally, all the material was very interesting, apart from just learning Hindi vocabulary and grammar. A weakness might be that sometimes some assignments were layered on top of one another and I had a large amount of work for the class -- but that only happened a few times.
The course at some points during the midterm felt like way too much work for just 1 credit but the language you learn is fruitful. And of course accommodations were made if needed.
Fantastic Professor and Conversation Teacher. Really enjoyed reading stories. Leave with a good foundation in Hindi language skills.

Strengths - was one of my fun classes this semester! The class was very close to each other despite the virtual format. The teachers are also very understanding and welcoming.
Weaknesses - the course can be kind of disorganized sometimes, but much improved since L3

There are so many strengths! Swapna Ji is absolutely great, and gives you lots of feedback and is happy to meet with you if you need help with something. The classes feel like you're chatting with family friends, and there is absolutely no judgement or social pressure, so you can be completely focused on just improving your Hindi. I would say that the only weakness is the way we learned the many different forms of grammar - it would have been great if we could have had a compilation of the different forms of vocabulary labelled, so that we could differentiate between them more easily and study them better. As it was, I had difficulty recognizing the different tenses by name.

Having a separate meeting time for a consistent conversation section was actually really helpful in improving my ability in speaking. There were a lot of concepts taught, and while there were also a lot of examples verbally given, it would've been helpful to write on a whiteboard simultaneously to show what all is being verbally discussed. This might just been a Zoom-related situation. A quick review of English grammar preceding discussion on certain Hindi concepts would also be helpful as in my English-learning experience, I was never formally taught sentence structures such as subjunctive/causative verbs/etc..

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Covid pracitices were fine

Great discussion sections even over Zoom.
Did presentations which worked well.
Wouldve love in person lessons but do not feel like learning was compromised by virtual format.
We had Hindi 4x a week which helped the consistency of practice
I think that everything was great! The only thing that I missed was having a whiteboard, but Swapna Ji did her best to send things in the Zoom chat instead.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! This is a wonderful course to better one's Hindi and learn a lot about South Asian and the diaspora in the process. Swapnaji is an amazing professor and really cares about her students -- I had so much fun learning with her this past year.
Yes, this course was really fun and I met great people because of it. I imagine that this course is super fun in person so please take it!
Yes! Its a great language credit and the small class makes it seem like a family :)

Undoubtedly. My favourite class at Yale so far. Especially for heritage students starting with very few Hindi language skills, this is an excellent class. Also, support is very individualized which is fantastic.
Yes! Have a fun time learning Hindi and meet some great people :)

Yes! If you know some Hindi and have some reading/writing abilities (Devanagari script), but want to expand your abilities or increase your confidence, this is a great class. The class feels like family, and you will really improve your skills.

The instructor is super helpful and responsive. The course is flexible with certain deadlines which aids in making it a lesser-stress learning environment. My peers and I were all so kind to each other, and we had an amazing time giving presentations about various topics in Hindi and talking to each other.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: virtual lectures with weekly discussion section and quiz
Live virtual lecture
NA
Readings and discussions during class.
